Graphical abstract Coenzymes are essential participants in the oxidoreductase-catalyzed reactions, but the stoichiometric consumption and high cost limit their applications. In this study, the reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) was regenerated with high efficiency via UV photocatalysis using original TiO2 nanoparticles as the catalyst, disodium salt of ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) as the electron donor and [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ as the mediator. When the loading amount of TiO2 was increased, the initial reaction rate first increased and subsequently remained almost unchanged. In the presence of 1.5mg/mL TiO2, the NADH yield reached approximately 90% after 30min of irradiation. Several electron donors were investigated. Disodium and tetrasodium salt of EDTA were demonstrated to be superior to triethanolamine, CH3OH, trisodium nitrilotriacetate monohydrate and H2O under appropriate pH conditions. The optimal concentration for disodium EDTA and rhodium mediator was 0.15 and 0.25M, respectively, and the preferred molar ratio of NAD+ to TiO2 and [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ was 1:0.1:0.25. Regenerative NADH was successfully applied in the enzymatic reduction of formaldehyde to methanol with a high conversion percentage (up to 95% after several minutes), which was notably close to fresh NADH. This work provides an alternative strategy to catalyst modification for the high-efficiency photoregeneration of coenzyme by optimizing the regeneration system. Keywords Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide Regeneration Photocatalysis TiO2 Electron donor 1 Introduction The biosynthesis involving oxidoreductase requires a cofactor to provide a functional group, such as hydride, phosphate and methyl, which is transferred to or from the other substrate during the reaction [1–3]. The reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH), which can confer hydride to the substrate [4], is the most often used coenzyme because the reaction in which it participates is simple and can be simulated in vitro for various industrial applications [5,6]. Unlike enzymes, coenzymes undergo chemical reactions with the substrates and become their corresponding reduced or oxidized forms. Thus, it is too expensive to use a stoichiometric amount of coenzymes in practical large-scale synthesis without regeneration [7–9]. Therefore, efficient and economical coenzyme regeneration techniques for reuse cycles are required. The basic principle of coenzyme regeneration is that via the redox reaction of hydrogenation or dehydrogenation, the coenzyme in an oxidized state or a reduced state transmutes into each other [10,11]. Coenzyme regeneration methods are generally divided into four categories based on the regeneration mechanism: enzymatic, chemical, electrochemical and photochemical methods [1,6]. Among them, the enzymatic pathway is the most selective and usually achieves the highest reaction rate, but a second enzyme and substrate are often required [12]. Although the traditional chemical method is relatively low-cost, its selectivity is not desirable, and it is often incompatible with enzymatic systems [1,5]. For the electrochemical approach, no additional co-substrates and auxiliary catalysts are required, but problems such as high over-potentials and electrode fouling must be solved [13]. The photochemical method enables the cofactor regeneration using clean and cheap light energy, which is notably promising and inherently sustainable [14,15], compared to the established but not optimal enzymatic pathway and electrochemical approach. TiO2 is widely used as the photocatalyst in the degradation of organic pollutants in air and waste water, sterilization, solar cells, etc. [16–18] because of its good chemical stability, low cost and high catalytic activity [19]. TiO2 also attracts great attention for its potential application in coenzyme regeneration [6,20]. However, in the few reports about non-enzymatic photoregeneration system with original TiO2 as the catalyst, the NADH yield was notably low [20,21]. In general, a semiconductor photocatalytic cycle comprises three steps. First, illumination induces the transition of electrons from the valence-band (VB) to the conduction-band (CB), which leaves an equal number of vacant sites (holes) on the VB. Second, the excited electrons and holes migrate to the semiconductor surface under the action of the electric field. Third, the electrons and holes react with the electron acceptors and electron donors, which are absorbed on the semiconductor surface, respectively. In the second step, a large proportion of electron-hole pairs recombine, which decreases the photocatalytic efficiency of TiO2 [22]. To reduce the recombination and improve the utilization efficiency of light energy, intense research endeavors have been centered on TiO2 modification and doping [23–25]. However, any modification or doping may introduce new problems such as complex procedures, increased cost, deteriorated catalytic performance under ultraviolet (UV) light, etc. [26]. In the current work, NADH was regenerated under UV radiation via a common TiO2 photocatalyst (P25). In addition to the irradiation time and loading amount of TiO2, the effects of the type and concentration of electron donors, pH value and the concentration of the rhodium mediator on the reaction were systematically investigated. With the increased concentration of NAD+, the appropriate ratio of the components was also studied. Finally, the biological activity of regenerative NADH was tested in the enzymatic synthesis of methanol from formaldehyde. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials TiO2 powder (P25, 20–40nm) was produced by Degussa Co., Ltd. NAD+ (≥98%), disodium salt of NADH (≥98%) and alcohol dehydrogenase from Saccharomyces cerevisiae (ADH, 337U/mg-solid) were commercially available from Sigma-Aldrich. Disodium and tetrasodium salt of ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (≥99%), EDTA-2Na and EDTA-4Na, were purchased from Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute and Fuchen Chemical Reagent Factory, respectively. Trisodium nitrilotriacetate monohydrate (NTA-3Na) (≥98%) was produced by Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. Triethanolamine (TEOA) and anhydrous ether were from Beijing Chemical works. Dichloro(pentamethylcyclopentadienyl)rhodium(III) dimer ([Cp*RhCl2]2) (≥99%) and 2,2′-bipyridine (≥98%) were from Alfa Aesar. Anhydrous methanol was from Fisher Scientific. Formaldehyde (37wt% aqueous solution) was from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ The rhodium complex (pentamethylcyclopentadienyl(2,2′-bipyridyl)rhodium(III) chloride ([Cp*Rh(bpy)Cl]Cl)) was synthesized according to the reported method [27]. First, 61.8mg (0.1mmol) red powder of [Cp*RhCl2]2 was added to 4mL anhydrous methanol. Second, 31.2mg (0.2mmol) 2,2′-bipyridine was introduced into the above suspension, and a yellowish homogeneous solution was immediately formed. Third, anhydrous ether was dropwise added into the solution at 4°C until orange [Cp*Rh(bpy)Cl]Cl particles precipitated, which were subsequently filtered and dried in a vacuum oven for one hour at room temperature. Finally, [Cp*Rh(bpy)Cl]Cl was added to deionized water that was readily hydrolyzed to [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+. A stock solution of 5mM was thereby prepared and subsequently stored at 4°C in the shield of light. The synthesis route is illustrated in Scheme 1 . 2.3 Photocatalytic reaction A schematic diagram of the photochemical regeneration system of NADH is shown in Scheme 2 . The photocatalytic reaction was performed at ambient temperature in a quartz vessel with magnetic stirring. Typically, 7.5mg TiO2 powder was added to 5mL EDTA-2Na-NaOH buffer solution (pH 7.0), stirred for 10min and treated with ultrasound for 15min. Then, NAD+ and [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ were successively loaded into the suspension with the final concentration of 1 and 0.25mM, respectively. The mixture was stirred and purged with nitrogen in the dark for 15min before the system was exposed to two 23W UV lamps with the major emission wavelength of 365nm. The sample was periodically taken from the vessel and centrifuged (10578 g) for 15min. Then, the NADH concentration in the supernatant was determined by measuring the absorbance at 340nm using a Unico 4802 UV–vis spectrophotometer. The NADH yield was calculated as the concentration of produced NADH divided by the initial NAD+ concentration. The initial reaction rate is the average formation rate of NADH within 15min. The EDTA-2Na-NaOH buffer solution was obtained by dropwise adding 3.0M NaOH solution to the aqueous solution of EDTA-2Na (0.15M) until pH value of the mixed solution increased to 7.0. With EDTA-4Na, NTA-3Na or TEOA as the electron donor, a 3.0M HC1 solution was used to adjust the pH value of the solution to 7.0. With methanol or H2O as the electron donor, a phosphate buffer (0.15M, pH 7.0) was used as the reaction medium. 2.4 Bioactivity test of NADH The bioactivity of NADH produced in the photocatalysis process was tested in the enzymatic reduction of formaldehyde to methanol. Certain amounts of ADH (7U) and formaldehyde (60mM) were blended into the isolated solution after the photocatalytic reaction for half an hour. Then, the change in absorbance at 340nm was monitored at room temperature using a UV–vis spectrophotometer. The blank experiment was performed under the identical conditions except for fresh NADH (0.9mM). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Irradiation time and loading amount of TiO2 The UV–vis scanning spectra of the sample solutions from the regeneration system irradiated for different time lengths are displayed in Fig. 1 a. As we observe, at the beginning (before the illumination), the sample solution had no absorption at 340nm. After 5min of irradiation, an obvious absorption peak at 340nm appeared and was gradually enhanced with the prolonged illumination time till 30min, which indicates the NADH formation. Correspondingly, first, the NADH yield rapidly increased with the illumination time; then, the conversion ceased at approximately 90% after 30min (Fig. 1b). In addition, the NADH yield slightly decreased when the illumination lasted for a longer time (for example, 90min). This decrease may be attributed to the decomposition of NADH in solution over time [28]. Fig. 2 shows the effect of the loading amount of TiO2 as the photocatalyst on the initial reaction rate. When the loading amount of TiO2 was increased from 0.1 to 1.5mg/mL, the initial reaction rate increased from (1.08±0.10)×10−2 to (3.48±0.23)×10−2 mM/min. When the loading amount of TiO2 was further increased from 1.5 to 2.5mg/mL, the initial reaction rate remained almost unchanged, which implies that the TiO2 concentration reached saturation. 3.2 Electron donor and pH value Electron donors are necessary for the stability of many photocatalysts in common reaction systems [29]. As sacrificial agents, electron donors can irreversibly react with the photoinduced holes and suppress the recombination of the photoinduced electrons and holes on the semiconductor surface [30]. Without the electron donor, the NADH yield dramatically decreased [31]. Hydrogen and mercaptoethanol are attractive electron donors because of their strong reducibility. Hydrogen is clean and abundant, but it easily leaks and explodes, and it has high requirements for the storage equipment and reactor [32]. Mercaptoethanol is pungent, toxic and expensive. Considering the cost, safety and environment, several types of electron donors such as EDTA-2Na, EDTA-4Na, TEOA, NTA-3Na, CH3OH and H2O were selected and compared (see Fig. 3 ), and the structures of some of them are shown in Scheme 3 . As shown in Fig. 3a, with EDTA-2Na, EDTA-4Na or TEOA as the electron donor, the NADH yield initially rapidly increased with time and subsequently remained unchanged or slightly decreased. The NADH yield at 90min was 85.0%, 82.5% and 44.2%. When CH3OH, NTA-3Na or H2O was the electron donor, the NADH yield slowly increased, no apparent plateau was observed until 90min, and the values in these systems were lower than 35% even after 90min of reaction. The initial reaction rate vs. the type of electron donor is plotted in Fig. 3b. Either the initial reaction rate or the final NADH yield was notably close in the system of EDTA, which indicates that there is not much difference between disodium and tetrasodium salt. Figs. 3a&b show that disodium and tetrasodium salt of EDTA are superior to the other types of investigated electron donors. The reason may be related to its particular structure. EDTA, which contains four carboxyl groups, can form complexes with TiO2 [33,34] and adhere to the TiO2 surface via strong chemical adsorption [30], whereas TEOA, CH3OH and H2O adhere to the TiO2 surface through the weak hydrogen bonding [29]. With NTA-3Na, which contains three carboxyl oxygen atoms, as the electron donor, the reaction rate was far lower than that of the EDTA system, which shows that the structure of ethylenediamine in EDTA may also be important in addition to the carboxyl groups. The effect of the EDTA-2Na concentration on the initial reaction rate was examined and is shown in Fig. 4 . The initial reaction rate first increased and subsequently decreased with the increase in EDTA-2Na concentration; the optimal concentration of EDTA-2Na was 0.15M. When the EDTA-2Na concentration was increased from zero (none) to 0.15M, the initial reaction rate increased from (0.403±0.071)×10−2 to (3.48±0.23)×10−2 mM/min. When the EDTA-2Na concentration was further increased to 0.2 and 0.25M, the initial reaction rate decreased to (2.45±0.15)×10−2 and (2.18±0.13)×10−2 mM/min, respectively. As hole scavengers, EDTA-2Na can provide electrons to the vacancies on the surface of the excited TiO2 nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the mediator relays the excited electrons from TiO2 to NAD+. At a lower EDTA-2Na concentration, the recombination of photoinduced electron-hole pairs may increase. However, a higher EDTA-2Na concentration will introduce excess valence electrons, some of which may be scavenged by basic hydroxyl groups on the TiO2 surface to generate ionized hydroxyl radicals (O−) instead of filling the holes, which causes the reoxidation of NADH [31]. The aqueous solution of EDTA-2Na is acidic; a typical pH value is 4.38 for the concentration of 0.15M. Either NAD+ or NADH is sensitive to the reaction environment [28], and the activity of the rhodium mediator also depends on the pH value of buffer solution [35]. Therefore, the pH value of the aqueous solution of EDTA-2Na was adjusted with different amounts of sodium hydroxide, and the initial reaction rate at different pH values was studied. As shown in Fig. 5 , when pH value increased from 4.38 to 7.0, the reaction rate increased from (0.429±0.021)×10−2 to (3.48±0.23)×10−2 mM/min. When the pH value was further increased to 7.5 and 8.0, the initial reaction rate decreased to (2.91±0.16)×10−2 and (1.39±0.06)×10−2 mM/min, respectively. Under acidic conditions, a higher concentration of hydrogen ions would facilitate the proton-driven oxidation of [Cp*Rh(bpy)H]+, which was associated with the release of H2 [11]; thus, the NADH regeneration was inhibited. Under alkaline conditions, in addition to the decomposition of NAD+ [28], [Cp*Rh(bpy)OH]+ in the system prevented further regioselective hydride transfer at C4 of NAD+ [36]. Eventually, the optimal pH value of 7.0 is consistent with the reported value [37]. 3.3 Concentration of [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ and the ratio of the components Because of the formation of 1,6-NADH in the protonation process and the dimers of NAD+ under the action of the intermediate radical [38], some transition metal hydrides as the electron relays and hydride catalysts are usually necessary to the selective production of biologically active 1,4-NADH. [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ is a versatile catalyst to promote biocatalytic redox transformations by regenerating the reduced nicotinamide cofactors [11,14,39]. The effect of its concentration on the initial reaction rate of NADH regeneration was studied in this work. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , the initial reaction rate was (0.602±0.07)×10−2 mM/min in the absence of the [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+. When its concentration increased from 0.1 to 0.25mM, the initial reaction rate rapidly increased from (1.62±0.10)×10−2 to (3.48±0.23)×10−2 mM/min. However, the initial reaction rate decreased to (2.93±0.15)×10−2 and (2.57±0.13)×10−2 mM/min when its concentration was further increased to 0.5 and 1.0mM, respectively. Because [Cp*Rh(bpy)H]+ as a hydride transfer reagent is significantly beneficial to reduce NAD+ to the biologically active structure of NADH, a lower [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ concentration decreases the formation rate of [Cp*Rh(bpy)H]+. Nevertheless, the reason that a higher [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ concentration decreases the reaction rate is not clear. Although the appropriate concentrations of several components were acquired for the photoreduction of NAD+, both initial reaction rate and NADH yield decreased when the NAD+ concentration was increased from 1 to 5mM with the constant amounts of TiO2, [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ and EDTA-2Na (see 1# and 2# in Table 1 ). The system with 5mM NAD+ had a comparable initial reaction rate to that with 1mM (1#) only when the amounts of photocatalyst and rhodium mediator were simultaneously increased (see 4#, 5# and 6# in Table 1). The preferred molar ratio of NAD+ to TiO2 and [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ was 1:0.1:0.25. It is also worthy to note that upgrading only the EDTA-2Na concentration or with the other components was adverse to the reaction, and the reaction rate decreased to (0.415±0.02)×10−2 and (0.753±0.038)×10−2 mM/min, respectively (see 3# and 7# in Table 1). 3.4 Enzymatic reaction The biological activity of regenerative NADH was examined in the enzymatic reduction of formaldehyde to methanol and is illustrated in Fig. 7 . The NADH concentration rapidly decreased and reached equilibrium within several minutes after formaldehyde was added into the enzymatic solution. Hence, the regenerative NADH is robust and can act as the coenzyme of dehydrogenase to catalyze the biotransformation reaction. Compared to the control system using fresh NADH in the absence of the rhodium mediator (black line), the enzymatic reaction using regenerative NADH exhibited a lower initial reaction rate. This difference mainly results from the inhibition of the rhodium mediator on ADH [40], which is proven by the result of another control system using fresh NADH in the presence of rhodium mediator (blue line) in Fig. 7. Eventually, (95±0.3)% and (98±0.4)% NADH was consumed for the regenerative and control system, respectively. This slight discrepancy may be because of the trace amount of 1,6-NADH, which formed in the photoregeneration process. 4 Conclusions With P25 as the catalyst, EDTA-2Na as the electron donor and [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ as the mediator, a simple UV-driven photocatalytic system was developed for coenzyme regeneration. The type and concentration of electron donor, pH value and rhodium mediator are vital to achieve a high regeneration rate. The particular structure of EDTA with strong complexing ability makes its disodium and tetrasodium salt a better type of electron donor than TEOA, NTA-3Na, CH3OH and H2O. The regeneration reaction is sensitive to the pH value of the medium, and the neutral condition is preferred. There are optimal concentrations of EDTA-2Na and rhodium mediator. Nevertheless, the TiO2 and rhodium mediator concentrations should be correspondingly increased when the NAD+ concentration is increased. Under appropriate reaction conditions and compositions, approximately 90% NADH can be photoregenerated after 30min, which shows excellent biological activity in the following enzymatic reaction. This work is inspiring in providing us an alternative for the high-efficiency regeneration of coenzyme by optimizing the photocatalytic system using a classical catalyst, which avoids the tedious modification or doping of the catalyst and reduces the cost. Ideally, this photochemical regeneration system can be applied in any enzyme-catalyzed redox reaction that NADH participates. Some challenges remain for the current system. As mentioned, the rhodium complex plays a critical role in achieving the high regeneration rate and product selectivity in the photocatalysis process. However, it is expensive, labile and soluble in the reaction media, and it is not easily separated and recycled. The rhodium complex also inhibits some enzymes. Immobilizing the rhodium complex on an insoluble matrix and keeping it out of touch with the enzyme are possible strategies to solve these issues. In addition, to avoid UV damage to the enzyme activity, enzyme immobilization and a relatively independent photoregeneration cell are necessary, and the reaction solution can be intermittently or continuously transported from the bioreactor to the photoregeneration cell. Further research in these aspects is underway. Organomet. Chem. 2010 380 385 [40] M. Poizat I.W.C.E. Arends F. Hollmann On the nature of mutual inactivation between [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ and enzymes-analysis and potential remedies J. Mol. Catal. B: Enzym. 63 2010 149 156

coredata.dc:description: Coenzymes are essential participants in the oxidoreductase-catalyzed reactions, but the stoichiometric consumption and high cost limit their applications. In this study, the reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) was regenerated with high efficiency via UV photocatalysis using original TiO2 nanoparticles as the catalyst, disodium salt of ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) as the electron donor and [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ as the mediator. When the loading amount of TiO2 was increased, the initial reaction rate first increased and subsequently remained almost unchanged. In the presence of 1.5mg/mL TiO2, the NADH yield reached approximately 90% after 30min of irradiation. Several electron donors were investigated. Disodium and tetrasodium salt of EDTA were demonstrated to be superior to triethanolamine, CH3OH, trisodium nitrilotriacetate monohydrate and H2O under appropriate pH conditions. The optimal concentration for disodium EDTA and rhodium mediator was 0.15 and 0.25M, respectively, and the preferred molar ratio of NAD+ to TiO2 and [Cp*Rh(bpy)(H2O)]2+ was 1:0.1:0.25. Regenerative NADH was successfully applied in the enzymatic reduction of formaldehyde to methanol with a high conversion percentage (up to 95% after several minutes), which was notably close to fresh NADH. This work provides an alternative strategy to catalyst modification for the high-efficiency photoregeneration of coenzyme by optimizing the regeneration system.
coredata.dc:title: Optimization of a photoregeneration system for NADH using pristine TiO2 as a catalyst
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis B: Enzymatic
